name: Circe
title: Greek - Circe
role: Goddess-Witch of Aeaea, Transformer of Men, Lover of Odysseus
summary: Circe, goddess and witch dwelling on the island of Aeaea, is one of the Odyssey's most memorable figures. Daughter of the sun-god Helios, she transformed Odysseus's men into pigs with her enchanted wine. Odysseus, protected by the herb moly given by Hermes, resisted her magic and became her lover for a year. She directed him to the underworld to consult Tiresias and warned him of the dangers ahead - Sirens, Scylla, Charybdis, and the cattle of Helios.
description: Circe, daughter of Helios and a nymph, is a divine witch dwelling on the island Aeaea. In Homer's Odyssey, she transforms men to swine with her drugs but is overcome by Odysseus with Hermes' aid. She becomes his lover and guide, directing him to Hades and warning of future perils.

homeric_context.role_in_epic: Transforms men to pigs, becomes Odysseus's lover and advisor, directs him to Hades

the_episode.arrival: Odysseus's advance party finds her palace and is transformed to pigs
the_episode.the_herb_moly: Hermes gives Odysseus the protective herb moly (black root, white flower)
the_episode.overcoming_circe: Protected by moly, Odysseus resists her magic and threatens her with his sword
the_episode.her_offer: She invites him to her bed; he stays a year
the_episode.her_guidance: She directs him to consult Tiresias in Hades and warns of dangers ahead

her_warnings: The Sirens and their deadly song
The cattle of Helios on Thrinacia

the_moly.description: A magical herb given by Hermes to protect Odysseus from Circe's drugs
the_moly.effect: Made Odysseus immune to Circe's transformation magic

sibling: Aeetes (king of Colchis, father of Medea)
Pasiphae (wife of Minos, mother of the Minotaur)
lover: Odysseus - for one year on Aeaea
